column37: The genus name Hieracium comes from the Greek word Hierax , which means sparrow hawk, and is based on the belief that hawks improved their vision with the help of the milky juice from the plant. Based on this old notion, herbalists in earlier times used the herb for eye problems, but this use is no longer current.

column37: ""blåklokke"" is a beautiful plant that everyone, both children and adults, knows. In the past, blåklokke had a special appeal to children, because the flowers could be used for many kinds of toys. All over Norway it was a common game of skill to try to turn the flower without it breaking. On rare occasions it was said that one also had to be able to turn it back. As usual with such games, it was almost always said that if it was successful, one or more wishes would be granted. It was also quite common for children to use the flower to slap. The little girls used the flowers as thimbles, or you could put them in your mouth and blow them out.

column38: An evergreen conifer, it has the largest geographical range of any woody plant, with a circumpolar distribution throughout the cool temperate Northern Hemisphere3. Male plants have tiny, yellow cones that shed wind-dispersed pollen. Female plants have berry-like, fleshy seed cones that become purple-black, with a waxy bloom, on maturity4.

column37:
Despite its cheerful appearance, the bird’s-foot trefoil symbolizes a warning of revenge in the Victorian language of flowers9.7. The scientific genus name Lotus is an old name for beautiful and useful plants, and is first mentioned by Homer ca. year 800 BC Corniculatus means ""with small horns"", and comes from the fact that the empty, cracked pods resemble small antelope horns.

It is uncertain how the Norwegian name tiril tongue may have arisen, but it could possibly be a comparison between the inflorescence, or preferably the fruit stand, and a tiril (or turul ), the kernel stick that was formerly used in the upright, cylindrical butter kernels. Tongue refers to the tongue-shaped fan in each individual flower.
column38: In folk medicine in Norway, the plant has been used to a small extent. To the extent that it was used, it was either in the form of a spirit extract of the flowers, or dried leaves and pods were used as tea, which was supposed to be good stomach medicine. The root of tiril tongue has been used as a blood purifier.

column37:
Prikkperikum has a great reputation in folklore and was widely used in magical rituals for protection. One had to pick the plant with the left hand, after asking permission. Wearing Prikkperikum protected against fevers and colds, made soldiers invisible and attracted love. Plants gathered on Midsummer's Eve or on a Friday and worn on the body kept mental illness at bay and cured melancholy. When Prikkperikum was placed in a window, it protected against lightning, fire and evil spirits. Both the flowers and the leaves could be used for this purpose. The herb could also be dried over the midsummer bonfire and hung near a window to keep ghosts, sorcerers and other ill-wishers away from the house, and it could be burned to banish spirits and demons.

If the plant was placed under the pillow of an unmarried woman, she would dream of her future husband. The herb could be used in rituals or carried to detect other magicians, and was once held to the mouths of accused witches in an attempt to force a confession.
column38: It has traditionally been used to treat burns, cuts, bruises and wounds. It is also known for its ability to fight depression, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), social phobia, and seasonal affective disorder (SAD)8. There was a myth told about this flowering plant5. This plant has marked diversity in strikingly diverse flowers and fruit67. The leaves are either palmately lobed or compound67. The sepals of the flowers are larger than the petals67.

column37: GRASS. Som beitegras har finnskjegg stort sett vært regnet som dårlig, og direkte farlig for hester: ”Merra hev fått troll når den var blitt syk av finnskjegg” (Ørsta). ”Det har henni at hestan har spist ihjæl seg på setervollan” (Meråker). Til tross for dette ble finnskjegg ofte tatt med i skraphøy fra utslåtter, noe som var mest vanlig i Trøndelag og Nordmøre: ”illt å slå når det e my finn” (Rindal), ”finnskjeggen må en slå tri gang (Glåmos), ”hera ho berre nekke te oss” (Tydal). Ble slått te sauene (Glåmos). ”Hèr er så halbett, vanskelig å få ljåen til å bite på” (Harran).”Bustingen flirer a oss” (Leksvik). ”I fjellet vaks det eit slag gras som dei kalla villgras. Ein måtte akta seg vel so ein ikkje kom ut på det, for så gjekk ein seg vill” (Verdal). ”Når stien vokste igjen av dette graset så den vandrende mistet den, var han kommet på villstrå” (Åsen).

column37:
Yellow ant is not an important medicinal plant these days, but there is a lot of information about its use in earlier times. In the Norse saga era, the yellow ant was consecrated to the fertility goddess Frøya and was therefore called frøyagrass. It was believed that placing a bundle of the herb in the maternity bed alleviated pain during childbirth. Placed in the child's cradle, it was supposed to keep witches and sorcery away. From Christian times, we have the legend that it was the sweet-smelling, soft, yellow-flowering ant that the Virgin Mary used in the manger for the baby Jesus. The old folk name Jomfru Marias sengehalm, which is known from many places in the Nordics, refers precisely to this popular legend. The English name of the plant, Lady's Bedstraw, alludes to the same.

The pleasant, honey-like fragrance of the flowers, and the smell of hay from the dried leaves, made this plant suitable for use as a stuffing in mattresses. It was often mixed with other aromatic herbs and ferns to help keep vermin away from the bed.
column38: Yellow ant has also been used as a beer spice, and has also had some use as a dye plant. The root gives wool a beautiful red colour, while alum-stained wool and silk get a bright yellow color from the above-ground parts. As a source of red color.
